nytimes_articles.headline: Media Feed
nytimes_articles.abstract:
It is a measure of the diminished self-esteem of this Administration that insiders no longer talk about having a good year, or a good month or even a good week. They're looking for a few good days. Last week they finally got five in a row. I happened to be there, and here's how they did it.

Monday: In his debut as the President's new counselor, David Gergen shows up in the press room to announce his decision to "turn the page" on 12:30 press briefings, which will hereafter be conducted at the more convenient time of 11:30. The announcement sends a shot of electricity through the room, as several reporters rush to the phones to make lunch reservations. Then, with great fanfare, Gergen cuts a red ribbon reopening the back offices to the press. Access-starved reporters surge forward into the previously off-limits back corridor, where a buffet of cold cuts and cheese cubes has been set up to welcome us. A string quartet plays in the background as we fan out to buttonhole press staffers we haven't seen since the election.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I felt very lucky that I had a skill and I didn't have to be a burden on the government. I could just carve out my own little corner in the United States, and sew and sew until the kids here were legal and the kids I left at home didn't need me anymore." -- LEIDA FERMIN, who runs a small illegal sewing factory in Manhattan.  [ 42:1. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: The Gift of a Difficult Life
nytimes_articles.abstract: ORDINARY TIME Cycles in Marriage, Faith, and Renewal. By Nancy Mairs. 238 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Unconventional College Finds Adults Are Good Students
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT Charter Oak State College in Connecticut there are no classrooms and no curriculum. It does have a faculty but its members don't teach. Ten percent of its students -- average age close to 40 -- live outside the state. Some even live outside the country. The college has no campus, but exists in a suite of rooms in a commercial office and shopping complex. It is a most unusual place.   It is also relatively unknown. Ask most people about Charter Oak and they might talk about the tree revered in early Connecticut history, where the colony's charter was hidden. But a college?

nytimes_articles.headline: No Excuses, No Solace As Big Names Stumble
nytimes_articles.abstract: Curtis Strange, Paul Azinger and Seve Ballesteros head into next week's United States Open under less than ideal circumstances after their showing at this week's Buick Classic.   These three, along with several other prominent players on the PGA Tour like John Daly, performed miserably in this week's tournament at the Westchester Country Club and missed the cut.

nytimes_articles.headline: Made-for-TV Mystery: What, if Anything, Do Yanks Owe City?
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is the biggest and most secretive television deal in local team sports history, one the New York Yankees and the Madison Square Garden Network discuss as openly as Coca-Cola executives discuss their soda formula. So shrouded is this deal that when New York City auditors wanted to view it, they were refused copies, and had to trek to Yankee Stadium like obsequious subjects doing their master's bidding.   "I've been trying to find out what the cable deal is for years," said Betsy Gotbaum, New York City's Parks Commissioner, whose department administers Yankee and Shea Stadiums and is responsible for collecting rent from the teams.

nytimes_articles.headline: Meditations on the Epidemic
nytimes_articles.abstract: MONOPOLIES OF LOSS By Adam Mars-Jones. 250 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

nytimes_articles.headline: Spielberg Grapples With the Horror Of the Holocaust
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a railway siding, a Nazi commandant and his servile lieutenants feast on fruit and drink punch from a crystal bowl while hundreds of terrified Jews -- penned in stifling cattle cars -- beseech their captors for water.   Sixty miles from Auschwitz, near the site where this horror unfolded a half century ago, Steven Spielberg was directing this scene from "Schindler's List." Based on the acclaimed 1982 book by Thomas Keneally, the film tells the story of a vain German businessman, Oskar Schindler, who saved the lives of his 1,300 Jewish factory workers at the height of the Holocaust.

nytimes_articles.headline: Demonstrations By the Masters
nytimes_articles.abstract: MORE than 100 years after Longfellow wrote his poem celebrating the village blacksmith, no fewer than 11 blacksmiths will bend and twist red-hot iron this summer at the Peters Valley Craft Center. They will show their students how to form Colonial-style hardware and candelabra in the early 19th-century forge.    In other studios, potters, fiber artists, woodworkers and jewelry makers will demonstrate traditional and innovative methods for creating contemporary crafts. Peters Valley is offering 70 workshops this summer.

nytimes_articles.headline: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: New York Hotels; New York City Hotels Battling the Blues
nytimes_articles.abstract: SEVERAL years ago, when Regent Hotels International decided to put up a 52-story luxury hotel at 57 East 57th Street, it seemed like a great idea. The New York economy was booming, hotels were commanding impressive room rates, and occupancy rates were high.    By last August, when the Four Seasons bought all the Regent properties, New York wasn't such a boom town anymore. The Four Seasons professed to be unworried. After all, the company, whose Pierre Hotel has been astriking success, would have its name emblazoned on a luxury property.

nytimes_articles.headline: Paris Airports Get Direct Link
nytimes_articles.abstract: Travel between Orly Airport south of Paris and Charles de Gaulle Airport at Roissy in the northeast can be completed entirely by rail and without getting into delays caused by city traffic. The Orlyval light rail automated train connects Orly South and Orly West terminals with the suburban R.E.R. B line at the Antony stop.   The two trains are on either side of the same platform and one usually leaves promptly after the other arrives.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Group Offers to Help the Ill Commit Suicide
nytimes_articles.abstract: A number of right-to-die advocates here have created what is apparently the nation's first organization intended to provide professionals who will help terminally ill people kill themselves.   It is unclear whether the organization's efforts violate the laws of Washington State, where the "promoting" of suicide has been illegal for almost two decades.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lee White, Sergio Galvis
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mary Lee White was married yesterday to Sergio Jordan Galvis, like her, a lawyer in New York. The Rev. John F. Halborg officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.   The bride, who is known as Lee, is an associate in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts who works in the counsel's office of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She graduated summa cum laude from Princeton University and received a law degree from Columbia University.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Than Merely Pop
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Regarding Edward Rothstein's essay "Beyond CD: Music Takes a Back Seat"  [ May 16 ] , I should like to note that the repertory of the world's most celebrated classical musicians is represented on DCC. Further, with more than 101 titles currently available in the United States on DCC and with an additional 23 titles scheduled for release before the end of the year, Polygram Classics and Jazz (representing the London, Deutsche Grammophon and Philips Classics labels) is very definitely committed to this new digital sound carrier.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lauren Ashburn and Paul Dueffert
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lauren Elizabeth Ashburn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren W. Ashburn of Wyomissing Hills, Pa., was married yesterday to Paul Keith Dueffert, the son of Shirley M. Dueffert of Waconia, Minn., and the late Orville Dueffert. The Rev. Anthony Mongiello, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Memorial Chapel at Albright College in Reading, Pa.   Ms. Ashburn, 25, is keeping her name. She is a news assistant at New York 1 News in New York. She graduated from Albright and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. Her father is the senior vice president of Kelly Michener Inc., an advertising agency in Lancaster, Pa. Her mother, Ellen Ashburn, is the director of reading and language arts for the Reading Public School District.

nytimes_articles.headline: Therapist Puts Twist On Tales of the Soul
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Amy Bloom is a presence: statuesque and poised, with dark almond eyes topped by strong, arched eyebrows, her luminous face framed by a raven bob.

She speaks in a velvety contralto that a diva might envy, a voice graced by intelligence, wit and candor. She looks and sounds like someone born to be in the limelight. The surprise is that she has chosen to avoid it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Albany Pressured to Draw Plans to Reduce Pollution
nytimes_articles.abstract: Imagine the impact on New York City traffic if large stretches of the Gowanus Expressway, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, and the Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges had to be shut down because there was no longer money for repairs.   That's the nightmare that state officials are depicting to prod the Legislature into enacting a plan that would meet the requirements of the Federal Clean Air Act before the current legislative session is scheduled to end June 25. Failure to do so could cost the state billions in roadway repair dollars.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jackson Leaves The Hunt For Hunted
nytimes_articles.abstract: Darrin Jackson left a defending World Series champion, a team two games out of first place in its division. He joined the second-worst team in baseball, a club so far down in the standing, it would take an amazing run just to get out of last place.   He says he's happy about it.

nytimes_articles.headline: Whistle Silenced, Cityspire Sales Resume
nytimes_articles.abstract: CITYSPIRE, the 73-story tower at 150 West 56th Street, is known for many things, not all of them flattering.   It was built taller than zoning rules allowed. It was supposed to have an arcade and rehearsal studio, which were never built. Then, it began to whistle so loudly that people 10 blocks away lost sleep on windy nights.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. Mandate Grows
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United Nations has expanded its mandate in peacekeeping operations with its attack on a Somali faction leader who is accused of killing Pakistani peacekeepers. But the action raises troubling questions about whether United Nations efforts must depend on United States firepower.    News analysis, page 16.

nytimes_articles.headline: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOW WE SURVIVED COMMUNISM AND EVEN LAUGHED By Slavenka Drakulic. Harper Perennial, $12. A Croatian journalist discusses life under Communism; it was filled with indignities large and small, from the lack of privacy to the lack of panty hose. Last year our reviewer, Cathy Young, called the book a "thoughtful, beautifully written collection."

nytimes_articles.headline: When Tour Groups Face Changing of the Guide
nytimes_articles.abstract: AN expert guide or star lecturer is often the selling point for a tour. It is sometimes a dicey one: the expert may fall ill or for another reason be unable to go.    When this happens, what is the responsibility of the travel company selling the trip? And what are the rights of the traveler? These questions, among the many that unfold in the chasm between a brochure and an actual trip, have tangled answers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; A Political Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: Discussions of political correctness on campus always puzzle me a bit, because they usually have as their starting point a view of the academy, in fact the world, that is contrary to established reality. That is, that into this calm pool of egalitarian rational discourse comes the bigfoot of racial and gender politics, ready to stomp down anyone who offends, diverges, challenges liberal orthodoxy.    The stomping part I understand. But that calm egalitarian pool? Oh, phooey, boys and girls.

nytimes_articles.headline: Device Makes Drunken Drivers Nonstarters
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A Manhattan bicyclist was dragged eight blocks after having been hit by a drunken driver, whose license had been repeatedly suspended and who was forbidden to drive (news article, June 1).    A technological development promises to reduce the problem of drunken driving by those who have lost their licenses: the ignition interlock device. Attached to a car's ignition, this miniaturized "breathalyzer" prevents the car from being started if the driver "blows" too high an alcohol reading. Circumvention seems less a problem than was feared, and there is reason to believe that the basic drinking habits of drivers may be altered.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Blizzard
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: I read the words of the disgruntled travelers in the Blizzard of '93 (Letters to the Editor, May 16) and felt I must show the other side.   Five of us, my sister, my daughter and two granddaughters and I, were traveling east from Salt Lake City on Saturday, March 13. My sister and I were changing planes in Chicago and then going on to Newburgh, N.Y. We were told we would get no farther than Chicago and when we arrived we should check with personnel there for information about a hotel room. My daughter and her two children were to change in Chicago for Syracuse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Leigh Weatherly, Anthony Flint

nytimes_articles.headline:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Tales of the Vienna Streets
nytimes_articles.abstract: An insightful photographic portrait, VIENNA 1850-1930: Architecture (Rizzoli, $65) provides a panorama of Viennese architecture during an era when the city was one of the most important intellectual and cultural centers in Europe. An essay by Peter Haiko, an architectural historian who teaches at the University of Vienna, provides a competent and accessible introduction to the historical events and theoretical issues for those unfamiliar with the architecture of the period. The heart of the book, however, is the fine color and black-and-white photographs of more than 30 structures documenting the metamorphosis of Vienna from a Baroque capital draped in the mantle of historicist styles to the stern, uncompromising forms of the modern city. In addition to civic and religious structures, the building types surveyed include private villas, apartment buildings and municipal structures like gasworks, water towers and bridges. Like the finest examples of human portraiture, Roberto Schezen's photographs reveal character as well as physiognomy. While his treatment of facades and major interior spaces conveys the public decorum and grand scale of urban architecture, his photographs of building details and eccentric spaces reveal intriguing facets of his subjects. Mr. Schezen possesses a wonderful eye for decorative details. The result is an unusually subtle and nuanced description of architecture. This photographic paean to Vienna vividly testifies to architecture's ability to transcend the requirements of mere shelter and evoke the spirit of an age and the character of a place.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. to Push Germany and Japan for U.N. Council
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration has told Germany and Japan it will soon start a campaign to fulfill its promise to support permanent seats for them on the Security Council.   Despite the Administration's position, diplomats said any effort to change the Security Council would run into difficulties. Britain and France, for instance, worry about losing their permanent seats and veto privileges.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Moncrieff, Mr. Buttrick

Mrs. Buttrick was until recently an institutional equity sales assistant at the First Boston Corporation in New York. nytimes_articles.headline: Why Not More Safety In Car Inspections?
nytimes_articles.abstract: I read with interest your May 23d article about Connecticut's success in selling special interest license plates. Fine! But there is another side of our Department of Motor Vehicle activity which is woefully inadequate: car inspections.   Connecticut does test annually for emissions. But there is no mandatory testing for lights or brakes. I talked to my representative and senator about this and was told to contact Commissioner Goldberg. His reply to me was that nothing could be changed without an act of the legislature.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Computers Could Link Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract:
REGARDLESS of the outcome of a metropolitan Hartford school desegregation lawsuit, black, white and Hispanic children from the suburbs and the city may soon find themselves collaborating on homework assignments, talking back and forth computer to computer.

Connecticut's test project, using computers, telephone lines and video equipment so children can see one another, is expected to involve elementary school students from Morley School in West Hartford and Annie Fisher School in Hartford, two racially and economically different neighborhoods.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brooke Silbersack and John Aymar 3d

Wayne Silbersack of Darien, Conn., was married on Thursday to John vanBeuren Aymar 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aymar Jr. of Darien. The Rev. Winston Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Swept Away Resort in Negril, Jamaica.   Mrs. Aymar, 24, is a student at Fordham University. Her father, now retired, was a vice president of Petersen Advertising in Freehold, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Giuliani Finds Well-Wishers in Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dressed in red, khaki and blue and pressing the themes of crime, drugs and educational failure, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, traversed Queens yesterday with a promise to "straighten this city out" by increasing arrests of drug dealers, reducing crime and slashing the size of city government.   His trip marked one of his most extensive street campaign efforts to date, and drew a largely positive response in a borough that backed him with more than 60 percent of the vote in the 1989 election.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Jazz Festival and Its Musical Muses; Jimmy Scott -- A Voice That Tweaks Souls
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 1993 JVC Jazz Festival, which runs from Friday to June 26, will be sleeker than in previous years. With 20 concerts at six locations throughout Manhattan, the schedule is heavy in singers and tributes (to the likes of Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker). And because of rising costs, many smaller events, like the afternoon piano concerts, have been dropped. But despite the leanness, the festival should still offer performances to satisfy the tastes of most jazz lovers. Here, six noted authors tell why a performer or honoree on this year's program speaks to them.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Pushes for a Smoking Ban on Flights Abroad
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to complaints and new worries about the effect of second-hand smoke, the Clinton Administration is working to speed the day when smoking is banned on all international flights into and out of the United States.   Currently, United States airlines allow smoking on all international flights, except to Canada. An international agreement adopted by a United Nations agency urges that smoking be banned on all flights between countries by 1996, but it has no enforcement provisions. So the Administration has begun trying to negotiate regional or bilateral agreements that would ban smoking for passengers and crew members without putting United States airlines at a disadvantage.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Stamford, Before or After the Show
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Stamford Center for the Arts in downtown Stamford has proved a magnet, with various restaurants opening in the immediate vicinity over a very short period of time.   Directly across from the center is Peppino's Ristorante, which is handy for theatergoers who want to dine before or after a performance. In fact, on a performance night recently, the first question the friendly and helpful head waiter asked us was if we were going to the theater. We made the mistake of saying no, and consequently waited and waited for our first course while tables all around us were served briskly. It pays to be in a hurry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brian O'Donoghue, Madeline Cuomo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Madeline Cerise Cuomo, a daughter of Gov. and Mrs. Mario M. nytimes_articles.headline: Kollek's Last Run May Be Toughest
nytimes_articles.abstract: Not many months ago, when he was a mere 81 years old, Mayor Teddy Kollek allowed that he had become too old to run for office again and that he himself would not vote for someone with so much mileage on him.   Now, a few weeks past his 82d birthday and deep into his 28th year of dominating Jerusalem City Hall, Mr. Kollek has decided that he has enough steam left, after all, for one more hurrah.

nytimes_articles.headline: To Arms! To Arms! White Fly is Here
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE goal now is to keep the garden blooming through the sunny months. If all goes well, everything should be nearly weedless and trouble free. This does require a few extra hours outdoors, but all too often uninvited troubles appear. One of the most discouraging is white fly.   These tiny insect pests seem to appear out of nowhere, and almost every kind of soft succulent leaf is to their liking. They keep away from a few annuals like impatiens and begonias, but vegetable gardeners know this nuisance well, especially on squash and tomato plants.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Sunday; Doing Lunch, And Dinner, And the Dishes
nytimes_articles.abstract: THERE are 250 million Americans and every one is convinced he can run his own business, typically a restaurant. This upscale suburb has been so besieged, village officials recently declared an eight-month moratorium on new restaurants.   Too many were failing, leaving vacant storefronts. "People think anyone can open a restaurant," said Nick Falcone, co-owner of two restaurants with his brother Glenn, a Pasta E Pesce here and in Plainview. "They come for dinner at 8, they see the big show, they see Glenn working the front, real smooth, they hear soft music, they say, 'We got to do this. We got to get a restaurant in Great Neck, make a million.' "

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P. Opposition Endangers Campaign Finance Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract: Campaign finance legislation may die in the Senate next week if Democrats cannot find a way to win a few Republican votes by modifying the bill's provisions for public financing of elections.   The issue that seemed the rage last fall when Ross Perot denounced the money in the political system has been stalled in the Senate. And even if legislation to limit spending and curb political action committees survives the Senate, it faces a difficult future in the rest of the legislative process.

nytimes_articles.headline: NIGERIANS IN VOTE FOR CIVILIAN RULE
nytimes_articles.abstract: After nearly a decade of military rule, Nigeria held its first free presidential election today against a backdrop of social unrest and disillusionment.   The exhilaration many Nigerians felt in 1986, when Gen. Ibrahim Babangida promised a swift return to elective civilian rule, has been supplanted by rising anger and anxiety over the sluggish pace of change.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 12-Year-Old With a Taste for Opera
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WITH more than 100 performances under his belt, including one on a forthcoming Kathleen Battle album, Eric Sadkin has a brilliant operatic career ahead of him.  Until his voice changes, that is.

As a member of the Metropolitan Opera's Children's Chorus, Eric, who turned 12 on June 5, has a decidedly different extracurricular activity. While most kids his age were memorizing rap numbers, Eric spent hundreds of hours in a windowless Met subbasement, practicing librettos in a half-dozen foreign languages.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Jersey Q & A: John A. Williams; A Novelist's Journey in Race Relations
nytimes_articles.abstract: THERE came a time, John A. Williams says, when he had to choose between taking an active role fighting racism or take up his pen and demand to be heard. In the end, he decided to be "totally a writer," he says, and his 20 books bear witness to his determination. And come this January, he will be able to devote even more time to his writing when he retires from Rutgers University in Newark, where for the last 14 years he has been a professor of English and journalism.   In an interview at his home in Teaneck, Professor Williams, 67, further talked about the relationship between blacks and whites in general, and blacks and Jews in particular; his his interracial marriage and the experience of teaching at Rutgers.   "No complaints," he insisted. "I'm talking about the facts of racism that have figured prominently in my life." They have also figured in the lives of the heroes of his novels.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Global Risk Seen in Nuclear Waste in Oceans
nytimes_articles.abstract: An international group of 116 scientists and radiation experts has reported that nuclear wastes dumped into the world's oceans over the decades apparently pose no global danger.   "Any potential problem would be a local one and would pose no threat on a global scale," the scientists said in a written statement issued on Thursday at a conference in Woods Hole, Mass.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Tell Mo Vaughn that you want to talk to him about his successes this season and he's liable to smile and shake his head.   It does not matter that he is one of the league's most torrid batters, and that in the last 24 games he has hit a sizzling .361, with four home runs and 15 runs batted in.

nytimes_articles.headline: Balanchine: Visions Without The Frills
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although George Balanchine was often choreographically unorthodox, few balletgoers would compare his art with modern dance. Yet it's possible to do so, and not just because he and Martha Graham created "Episodes" in 1959. That project was a pairing, rather than a collaboration: two independently choreographed works to music by Webern that were performed on the same program.    Balanchine, the familiar argument runs, was a product of ballet's most classical traditions. But this stance overlooks the questing spirit that led him to what was known from the 1920's onward as Absolute Dance. Among the milestones along Balanchine's journey toward that form are "Apollo" (1928), "Concerto Barocco" (1941), "Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2" (1941) and "The Four Temperaments" (1946). All four have been splendidly danced by the New York City Ballet during its current "Balanchine Celebration." To see these works at the New York State Theater and to compare them with the way they were said to look when new is to gain insights into how Balanchine developed his own Absolute Dance.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Humane' Isn't The Right Word
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   George Vecsey hints that the thoroughbred racing business "carries the fin de siecle gloom of being yesterday's sport" (The Times, June 6). After Prairie Bayou's horrible breakdown in the Belmont Stakes, I hope his thought becomes a reality. Too many horses are breaking down in too many races.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
Protests, 11 Sculptors and Man Ray
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"The Art of Protest"
 Benton Gallery, 365 County Road 39, Southampton. Daily except Tuesdays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Through June 23. 

There have always been artists who respond to the concerns of their era by creating work that makes a statement about an issue. This anthology concentrates on that tradition as it has occurred in the 20th century.  Starting with Kathe Kollwitz's powerful 1902 etching "Insurrection," which features a crowd of animal-like humans who are charging forward with hand-fashioned spears, it goes on to use examples by about 40 artists in an attempt at a very wide sweep.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
Full of Flavor, but Not Overly Rich
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WITH its casual steakhouse decor and greenhouse facade, Esty Street in Park Ridge looks a lot like a formula chain restaurant -- but don't let that fool you. The kitchen at this new Bergen County dining spot turns out some unexpectedly au courant and flavorful food, which is served by a well-trained staff. 

Far from standard roadhouse fare are starters like gossamer ravioli of sea scallops and wild mushrooms resting in a garlicky herb sauce, or main courses like buttery medallions of veal tenderloin with shiitake and Pommery mustard sauce atop a spinach nest and accompanied by chive mashed potatoes -- not to mention desserts like a trio of little shortcakes filled with mixed berries.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Summer Ritual: Music Out-of-Doors
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE collaboration of musicians and the out-of-doors in Beethoven's Ninth or Bach's Brandenburgs, or even Schubert's "Trout" Quintet, can be quite glorious even when it encompasses the occasional cricket solo or thunderclap percussion. Sometimes it even includes a seascape as backdrop or intoxicating gardens in full bloom. And if one is truly fortunate, nature's own Klieg light, the moon, illuminates a masterpiece. And always there is the barely audible rustle of sheet music.    Over the next few weeks a pleasant cacophany of creatures and natural phenomena will join with classical musicians in the perennial union. And Connecticut, with its Berkshire foothills to the north and seascapes to the south, offers a variety of settings for the quintessential summer ritual. One can board a 19th-century steamship in Mystic and revel in authentically performed Renaissance music while cruising the Sound. Or, on a mountaintop in Falls Village just above the Appalachian Trail, a music lover can absorb string quartet music in a shed built to resonate like the interior of a violin. Festival venues range from the intimate to the grandiose. And while most of the settings encourage spreading a picnic on a grassy knoll or cracking a croquet ball while a brass quintet plays some buoyant preconcert selections, at the moment of truth -- the concert itself -- the music making is anything but casual.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bernstein: Yet More Surprises?
nytimes_articles.abstract: If anyone still doubts Leonard Bernstein's status as an American folk hero, the matter should be put to rest this summer. Bernstein's 75th birthday, on Aug. 25, will be celebrated worldwide, beginning on Monday with the New York Philharmonic's weeklong tribute to its former music director. Sony Classical is scheduled to complete its massive 119-CD "Royal Collection" of Bernstein recordings by the end of the year, and Deutsche Grammophon's release of his final recordings is now complete. With all the Bernstein videos flooding the market, it is only a matter of time before someone in Nashville, where Bernstein's archives now reside, "sights" him leaping passionately into the air at the climax of Mahler's "Resurrection" Symphony.   Passion is what Bernstein's music-making was all about. In his concerts, recordings, teaching, writing, speaking, one always sensed a life-or-death need to communicate the composer's message. Always controversial, he was damned in many quarters for exhibitionism on the podium, for exaggerating the music's emotional content at the expense of its structural integrity, for vulgarizing a dignified art form. In his early days and well into his Philharmonic tenure, critics labeled his interpretations brash and immature. Yet his audiences grew inexorably. Today, listeners to his recordings from that era join Stravinsky in saying "Wow!"

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Menace II Society' Stakes a Claim to Bleak Turf
nytimes_articles.abstract: When two black teenagers, Caine and O-Dog, walk into a Korean grocery at the start of "Menace II Society," the store owner and his wife see a dangerous pair. Quite possibly, the audience does, too. O-Dog's pants are slung fashionably low, showing several inches of his boxer shorts; the boys shuffle in as if they own the place, and O-Dog opens his quart bottle of beer while walking toward the cash register. They look and act like what they are -- members of the hip-hop generation, where attitude is everything -- but the Koreans obviously think they are about to be robbed.    It takes no time for the difference between Caine and O-Dog to become clear, though, and for viewers to realize that the violent, provocative "Menace II Society" is about seeing beyond stereotypes. O-Dog (Larenz Tate) shoots the grocer because the man has said, "I feel sorry for your mother." Then he kills the wife. Caine (Tyrin Turner) doesn't kill anyone until days later, and then only as revenge for his cousin's murder. Though Caine grew up in Watts, the son of a drug-addicted mother and a drug-dealing father, he had never killed before. "I never had a reason," he says.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Long Island Q&A;: David Bouchier;
A Sociologist's Quizzical View of L.I.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FANS of public radio are getting a twice-weekly dose of the offbeat commentaries of a journalist and sociologist from Long Island, David Bouchier.  Initially broadcast as a trial, his essays are now regular features of "Morning Edition" and "Radio Pages" on Monday and Saturday mornings 

Mr. Bouchier's British accent and gentle wry wit may explain some of the appeal. But many listeners are equally charmed by the peculiar spin that he puts on everyday phenomena.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tito Puente's Rhythms Inspire a Painter
nytimes_articles.abstract:
REARED in an upper-class Cuban family transplanted to America, Yolanda Suarez Merchant frequently felt the pull between two cultures.  Just 5 when her family fled Cuba for Miami, rural Iowa and, eventually, Southampton, the issue was whether she would she be a product of her close-knit clan or adopted environment. 

"The other day I came across a picture of me that appeared in the social column of The Southampton Press," Ms. Merchant said. "It was taken on my 10th birthday, and there I was in a white lace dress my grandmother had made for me and wearing my little white gloves.

nytimes_articles.headline: Do Contests Need a Winner?
nytimes_articles.abstract: A string of performers take the stage in turn. Each grasps at a moment in the spotlight, trying to outstrip the others in the eyes and ears of a select, slightly benumbed jury seated in the auditorium. Each hopes, in effect, to be judged best. Anything less than No. 1 is a defeat.   A musical competition? Yes and no. It could be the Ninth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, which recently ended here. But it could just as well be "real life": an audition for a spot in a major orchestra, perhaps. Many argue nowadays that competitions, for all their venerable precedents, have no place in an artistic setting and should be confined to the sporting arena. But competition has always been a fact of life in the arts as well as in the businesses surrounding them. To suggest otherwise is naive.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Schmoozing': Time Well Spent
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As a biographer of Leonard Bernstein, I should like to clarify a statement about him that James Oestreich made in his portrait of Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic  [ "Speak Loudly, Carry No Stick," May 23 ] . Bernstein did not "routinely" waste "the first half-hour of rehearsal with talk and pleasantries." Bernstein led more than 1,200 Philharmonic performances in a 47-year relationship that included 11 (1958-69) as music director. You don't establish a record like that if you "routinely" spend 20 percent of your rehearsal wasting time.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Jazz Festival and Its Musical Muses; Gal Costa -- Forget Snow Tires; Go Dancing
nytimes_articles.abstract: The 1993 JVC Jazz Festival, which runs from Friday to June 26, will be sleeker than in previous years. With 20 concerts at six locations throughout Manhattan, the schedule is heavy in singers and tributes (to the likes of Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker). And because of rising costs, many smaller events, like the afternoon piano concerts, have been dropped. But despite the leanness, the festival should still offer performances to satisfy the tastes of most jazz lovers. Here, six noted authors tell why a performer or honoree on this year's program speaks to them.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Connecticut Q&A;: Michael B. Jones;
A Few Simple Rules for Biking Safety
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN Michael B. Jones began to talk to other Weston residents about bicycle safety, he heard four remarkable stories in just one week. One child, not wearing a helmet, rode his bike directly into the path of an oncoming car, flew right over it and somehow was unhurt. Another, whose mother allowed him to ride down the street on his tricycle without a helmet once, flipped over and had to have stitches in his forehead. And a third, an adolescent not in the habit of wearing a helmet, but doing so, lost control of her bike and smashed into a tree; the helmet was destroyed, but she was fine.

Those stories and a host of attention-grabbing statistics are among the tools Mr. Jones employs in his crusade for safe cycling. With the AAA club in Connecticut and several other sponsors, Mr. Jones recently held a statewide conference on safe cycling at the Waterbury Sheraton. The conference's objective: to put the issue on the legislative agenda and to get the attention of the insurance industry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Police Who Cut Through Red Tape
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE children who were waiting idly for the morning school bus in their apartment complex's parking lot eagerly ran over to the two adults who pulled into a parking space near the building's side entrance. The children exchanged high fives and greetings with the two men, who asked them about homework, problems with siblings and classmates and their after-school plans.   Such a display of enthusiasm was a cheerful sight on a late May morning, yet hardly surprising for what seemed to be a friendly exchange between neighbors.

nytimes_articles.headline: America's Prince of Promotion, P. T. Barnum
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FLASHING lights, colorful flags and red-and-white-stripe tenting draw visitors into a symphony of sounds where the Beatles belt out "I Want To Hold Your Hand" and Luciano Pavarotti sings "Maria." In celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport, a big, brassy exhibition, "Barnum, the Beatles and Batman: A Century of Promotion in American Life," is on view there through Nov. 28. 

In bringing together these unlikely bedfellows, the connection is made between themes and ploys used in the 1850's by P. T. Barnum, America's prince of promotion, and advertising over the last century.

nytimes_articles.headline: EASTERN CAMBODIA MOVES TO SECEDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Civilian and military leaders of the Vietnamese-installed Government said today that most of the eastern half of the country was seceding and would form an "autonomous zone" outside the jurisdiction of the United Nations peacekeeping force here.    The announcement was made as the United Nations ordered virtually all its civilian peacekeepers out of three large eastern provinces, where Government soldiers have threatened them at gunpoint in recent days.

nytimes_articles.headline: Budget-Makers Try to Soften Election-Year Blow
nytimes_articles.abstract: Faced with a difficult fiscal squeeze, Mayor David N. Dinkins and the leadership of the City Council have fashioned a recession election-year budget planned so that most New Yorkers will not notice it over the next few months.    Those next few months, of course, are an important political season in the city. Both the Mayor and the Council members hope that the spending cuts are gentle enough and the stabilization of taxes reassuring enough to most New Yorkers that the city's fiscal straits will not be on their minds come Election Day. This is not a buoyant budget, but it is one they can run on.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Chance to Reach Every Boy's Dream
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN this all-American town where the Revolutionary War battle of Heathcote Hill was fought, James Fenimore Cooper began writing, Matt Dillon began acting cool and the victorious 1987 America's Cup boat Stars & Stripes was built, the Chiou brothers, Frankie and Sonny, led the high school baseball team to the No. 1 ranking in the county. In addition, Frankie, a four-year varsity player, looms as a serious contender to become the first Chinese-American player in the major leagues. 

Anchoring the left side of the Mamaroneck High School infield at shortstop and third base, sometimes batting first or second in the lineup, always sitting side by side on the bench and wearing Nos. 7 and 8, Sonny, in his junior year, and Frankie, a senior, spurred their team to a 16-3-1 regular season record. 
Clash With State Champs

 Mamaroneck cruised into the playoffs last week as the No. 2 seed in the section's Large School A Conference. After disposing of Mount Vernon and Clarkstown South in the preliminary rounds, the Tigers clashed in the finals with North Rockland, the No. 1 seed and last year's state champion team.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Music Ever Mute On Politics?
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Wilhelm Furtwangler took the witness stand during de-Nazification hearings after World War II, he was challenged to defend his past. Hadn't he, as music director of the Berlin Philharmonic, been a central figure in the Nazi cultural apparatus? Didn't he lend his prestige to the murderous regime instead of leaving in protest? Furtwangler testified: "It was my intention -- and this is the reason I did not leave Germany -- to prove that art means more than politics."   He was more than a bit naive. In a recent Furtwangler biography, "The Devil's Music Master," Sam H. Shirakawa argues that the conductor consistently fought the regime from within, even aiding Jewish musicians; Furtwangler believed that great music could remain unsullied by Nazi pressures. But it is clear that art cannot be completely separated from politics. Art can be a tool of politics; it can use politics. Some even assert that art is simply politics by other means. It is certainly not a world apart.

nytimes_articles.headline: Focus: Beaufort, S.C.; Putting an Old Saw to Work in the South
nytimes_articles.abstract: HERE in this riverside city of 10,000, where gracious mansions were seized early in the Civil War by Union forces, a new invader has stormed the town. As before, the draw is real estate.   With its picturesque harbor, quaint downtown and elegant homes, Beaufort (pronounced BYEW-furt) has become a favored location for moviemakers. While one production company was filming in a rural area outside town at the end of May, Paramount was scouring the city with a real estate broker, looking for just the right house.

nytimes_articles.headline: Travel Medicine
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: In the Practical Traveler column on travel medicine (May 16), Betsy Wade said that "the traveler must be sophisticated or persistent" in order to get the right immunizations. An experience of mine says that the traveler must be both.   Several years ago, a minor complaint brought me to the office of the best primary care physician I have ever had. A report in the Travel Advisory in the previous couple of months had said that polio was present in a country to which my husband and I would soon be traveling.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Coventry;
Mementos of a Revolutionary War Hero
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FEW spectators were about when late on the morning of Sept. 22, 1776, Nathan Hale was led by the British to what was then known as Artillery Park in New York, and to his fate, the gallows.

As history has it, it was there that Hale, just 21 and an officer and spy for the Continental Army, uttered the words that have become synonymous with patriotism: "I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country."

nytimes_articles.headline: Learning More About Learning Disabilities
nytimes_articles.abstract: I want to commend the article ("What 'Learning Disability' Means," May 30) and Beryl Kaufman for further informing the public about learning disabilities.   Because those individuals with learning disabilities are of at least average intelligence, it should be emphasized that they can learn as well as their average intelligent peers and should be given every opportunity to do so. We all have different learning styles. Each of us uses a variety of strategies with which we receive, store and retrieve information in order to learn about and evaluate our environment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Science Fiction
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE HAMMER OF GOD (Spectra/Bantam, $19.95), by Arthur C. Clarke, is a novel expanded from a short story published last fall in a special issue of Time magazine entitled "Beyond the Year 2000." Nobody but Mr. Clarke could write such a cheerful tale about an asteroid on a deadly collision course with the earth.   As Mr. Clarke points out in the text itself and in an informative afterword, the scenario he imagines is by no means unlikely. Many scientists now believe that a collision with an asteroid precipitated the climatic changes that killed off the dinosaurs some 65 million years ago. In this century alone, at least three encounters with smaller chunks of cosmic debris have caused localized devastation on a scale matched only by nuclear explosions. Concern over future encounters has prompted the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to propose an international survey program to keep track of all asteroids and comets whose orbits might someday intersect the earth's. NASA's suggested name for this program, the Spaceguard Survey, is borrowed from a fictional effort described in Mr. Clarke's classic novel "Rendezvous With Rama," which was published in 1973.

nytimes_articles.headline: Behind SUNY's Choice for New President
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE lengthy and open process that led to the appointment here last month of Bill Lacy as the next president of the State University of New York at Purchase caused a serious rift between nearly half the members of the presidential search committee and the College Council, the college's board of trustees, who are legally entrusted with such appointments.   At issue was not so much the council's choice of Mr. Lacy, a former president of Cooper Union in Manhattan and the American Academy in Rome, but its dealings with the search committee itself, an advisory group representing all segments of the college.

nytimes_articles.headline: Northwest Indian Treasures
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE Cascade Mountains run like a spine down the backside of the Pacific Northwest, splitting Oregon into two distinct landscapes. The west is wet, a verdant rain forest. The east is dry and sunny, a sagebrush ocean washing across red soil. The difference in terrain seemed as clear to me as a geology exhibit during a recent 100-mile drive from Portland to the Warm Springs Reservation, home to three Indian tribes whose stories are intricately connected to the land east of the mountains. I planned to visit the Museum at Warm Springs, which opened in March to showcase a large collection of tribal art, and spend a weekend at Kah-Nee-Ta, a resort built at a hot springs on the reservation.   As Highway 26 crossed the Blue Box Summit, about an hour's drive from Portland, and began its descent off the eastern face of Mount Hood, the narrow, wooded view opened to frame a broad expanse of high desert. Clouds thinned into threads above red-rock volcanic columns. On this side of the Cascades, the air is drier, the light brighter, the horizon wider. Snow-capped mountains stretch across the horizon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Areas Fight Radar-Tower Sites
nytimes_articles.abstract: RESIDENTS of North Bellmore and East Hills are uniting to fight the construction of two radar towers that the Federal Aviation Administration is proposing for their neighborhoods.    The towers, part of a $350 million Terminal Doppler Weather Radar system for 47 airports, would enable air-traffic controllers to detect sudden wind shifts, gusts and heavy rains that can threaten takeoffs and landings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Christopher Gives Turks Plan to End Rights Abuses
nytimes_articles.abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher asked Turkish leaders today to cooperate with a detailed American proposal to help end widespread human rights abuses in the country, he and other Administration officials said.   At the same time, the United States announced that it would provide Turkey with $336 million in aircraft and other military equipment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Summer Job Prospects On L.I. Take Dim Turn
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SUMMER-JOB prospects on Long Island are so grim that unemployed adults and college students have already locked up virtually all the few jobs traditionally taken by high school students.

"The summer-job outlook this summer is worse than last summer," the employment coordinator of the Nassau County Youth Board, Vincent J.  Roccaro, said. "The private sector is tougher in terms of even considering hiring young people. I'm getting feedback from companies that are downsizing, and they don't feel comfortable letting go of permanent employees and then hiring seasonal ones."

nytimes_articles.headline:
TRACK AND FIELD;
Sprinters Notch Triples In State Championships
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Sprinters Stacey Minott of New Rochelle and Jermaine Stafford of Rochester turned in brilliant performances today at the New York State Interscholastic Boys and Girls Outdoor Track Championships at Dietz Stadium here. New York City's Public Schools Athletic League boys' squad won the team title, but the P.S.A.L. girls were upset by Section 1 (Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Orange and Rockland Counties). 

Minott, a 15-year-old sophomore at New Rochelle High School, erased meet records in the 100 meters with a winning time of 11.78 seconds and in the 200 meters at with a 23.85 seconds. Then, in her eighth and final race in the two-day meet, Minott touched off in second on the anchor leg of the 400-meter relay and brought her team home first in 47.77 seconds.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Winery Makes an Auspicious Debut
nytimes_articles.abstract: ROBERT PELLEGRINI is nearly 55. His wife, Joyce, is 55. At that age many people are thinking about retirement. But the curtain rises on a new life for the couple, from Cutchogue, on Saturday, when their nearly $2 million winery and estate, Pellegrini Vineyards, opens to the public.   Pellegrini Vineyards, on the 36-acre site of the old Island Vineyards, joins eight other wineries on Route 25, or Main Road, which by now deserves to be called Grape Alley. The boutique winery faces the traffic, with nearly all its 30 acres of mostly low-lying vines lying to the rear and heading off in neat rows into the north-northwest. The winery was designed by two architects from Cutchogue, Thomas Samuels and Nancy Steelman.

nytimes_articles.abstract: The associations are many: mobsters, lounge lizards, wise guys in general.    These 100 percent polyester double-knit shirts by Roberto Carlo, an English company, call for pointy-toed shoes and slicked-back hair.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perspectives: The MacArthur Portfolio; New Ownership for Unsold Apartments
nytimes_articles.abstract: SHUDDERS reverberate through the spines of many Lincoln Towers residents when they contemplate the prospect of a new Lincoln West thrown up between themselves and the Hudson River. But Daniele D. Bodini doesn't feel that way at all.   Mr. Bodini -- his first name is pronounced dan-YELL-ee -- is the new owner of 1,110 apartments in Lincoln Towers (1,081 residential, 29 professional). He is confident that values are going up, and he thinks they'll go higher if Donald Trump puts up expensive new apartments at Lincoln Towers' western doorstep. Many resident owners probably think that way, too.
